content.title: Decision Fatigue and Ego Depletion: Cognitive Resource Theory
content.summary: The psychological phenomenon of deteriorating decision quality after prolonged decision-making, including mechanisms, evidence, and prevention strategies
key_points: Decision fatigue is the deterioration of decision quality after prolonged decision-making
Ego depletion model: self-control draws from a limited cognitive resource
Depleted willpower leads to decision avoidance, impulsivity, or poor choices
Glucose metabolism is linked to self-control capacity
Morning decisions tend to be higher quality than afternoon/evening decisions
Reducing trivial decisions preserves energy for important ones
Strategic breaks and meals restore decision-making capacity

statement.text: Decision fatigue occurs when the act of making decisions depletes a finite cognitive resource associated with the prefrontal cortex, leading to impaired judgment, increased impulsivity, or decision avoidance. The ego depletion model proposes that self-control and effortful decision-making draw from a common, limited pool of mental resources.
statement.formal: Decision Quality = f(Initial Capacity - Cumulative Decisions - Time); Quality ↓ as Decision Count ↑

explanation.intuition: Think of your decision-making ability like a smartphone battery. Every decision - even small ones - drains a bit of charge. By late afternoon, after hundreds of decisions, you're running on low power mode, making you more likely to choose the default option, avoid decisions entirely, or make impulsive choices.
explanation.key_insight: The brain doesn't distinguish between important and trivial decisions when depleting willpower reserves. Choosing breakfast, picking what to wear, and whether to make a phone call ALL draw from the same limited pool. Smart decision-makers pre-decide trivial matters to save capacity for what matters.

definitions_glossary.decision_fatigue: Deteriorating quality of decisions after prolonged decision-making session
definitions_glossary.ego_depletion: State of reduced self-control capacity after exerting willpower; proposed by Baumeister
definitions_glossary.cognitive_load: Total amount of mental effort being used in working memory
definitions_glossary.willpower: Self-control capacity to resist short-term temptations for long-term goals
definitions_glossary.decision_avoidance: Tendency to postpone or avoid making decisions when fatigued
definitions_glossary.status_quo_bias: Preference for current state when decision capacity is low
definitions_glossary.choice_overload: Cognitive paralysis from too many options

ego_depletion_model.original_theory: Baumeister RF, et al. (1998) - Self-control as limited resource
ego_depletion_model.mechanism: Sequential decisions → Depletion of prefrontal cortex resources → Reduced executive function → Impaired self-regulation → Increased reliance on heuristics/defaults → Decision quality deterioration

supporting_evidence.glucose_connection: Self-control tasks correlate with blood glucose levels; glucose restoration improves performance (Gailliot 2007)
supporting_evidence.judicial_decisions: Danziger study (2011) showed parole decisions favored status quo late in session, reset after meals
supporting_evidence.consumer_behavior: Decision fatigue leads to impulsive purchases and acceptance of defaults

critiques_and_limitations.replication_concerns: Some ego depletion studies have failed to replicate
critiques_and_limitations.alternative_models: Process model suggests fatigue reflects motivation shift, not resource depletion
critiques_and_limitations.individual_differences: Effect size varies substantially across individuals

biological_basis.prefrontal_cortex: Primary executive control center; most metabolically demanding brain region
biological_basis.glucose_hypothesis: Brain glucose utilization increases during demanding cognitive tasks
biological_basis.dopamine_system: Reward processing affects decision effort allocation

manifestations.decision_avoidance: Postponing choices, going with defaults, saying 'I don't care'
manifestations.impulsivity: Making quick, unreflective choices to reduce cognitive load
manifestations.reduced_self_control: More likely to eat unhealthy food, skip exercise, overconsume alcohol

pre_decide: Reduce trivial daily decisions through routines
Use decision frameworks to reduce cognitive load
protect_peak_hours: Reserve first 2 hours for priority decisions
Avoid trivial decisions before important ones
restore_capacity: Eat regular meals with protein and complex carbs
Light exercise can reset cognitive function
reduce_load: Simplify routines to eliminate repeated decisions
Use checklists to eliminate repeated decisions

cross_domain_references.application_notes: Decision fatigue affects purchasing decisions and susceptibility to defaults
Meeting scheduling and break policies should account for decision fatigue

definition.@value: The psychological phenomenon of deteriorating decision quality after prolonged decision-making, attributed to depletion of a limited cognitive resource

learning_objectives: Understand the cognitive mechanism of decision fatigue
Evaluate the ego depletion model and its critiques
Implement strategies to preserve decision-making capacity
